_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION / EMERGENCY RESPONSE AT Agfinity Incorporated, Henderson, Colorado.

This facility complies with ANSI Standard K61.1 requirements for Anhydrous Ammonia storage and handling. It is our policy to adhere to applicable Federal, State, and local regulations. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the Brighton Fire District (via 911 calls) and request that it respond to the emergency. Incidental to the notification to the fire district, a call will be made to the Adams County LEPC and the Colorado Department of Public Health & Environment. If there is a Reportable Quantity (RQ) release a call will also be made to the National Emergency Response Center. Finally, other emergency response agencies may also be contacted.

While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may very well be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have been planned. In reality, every situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it was planned. In that event, what may have been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.

The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e., Anhydrous  Ammonia, aqua ammonia, etc.), tornadoes, bomb threats, or other accidents of acts of God which might occur on our property.

The primary emergency coordinator for the Agfinity Incorporated at Henderson, Colorado is Chip Marks, V.P. Agronomy. His work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided in the Registration Section of this document. In addition, the following individuals (with associated work and 24-hour emergency response numbers) are to be contacted in order:

	Chip Marks, V.P. Agronomy 
		WORK:		(720)685-1954
 		24-hour:	(303) 476-1120

	Gar

y Karmen, operations
		WORK:		(303) 659-3643
		Cell:		(303) 356-0991
		Home:		(303) 659-8762

	Glen Ross, Safety Coordinator
		WORK:		(303) 659-1230
		Cell:		(303) 579-0185

DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA AND AQUA AMMONIA STORAGE / DISTRIBUTION PLANTS AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED AT: Agfinity Incorporated.

This facility consists of bulk anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia storage and distribution plants. The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at this facility is distributed to agricultural producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes. Anhydrous ammonia is also reacted with water to form aqua ammonia (Ammonium Hydroxide) which is utilized by area water treatment and power generation plants.

The anhydrous ammonia plant consists of two (2) storage tanks with associated piping, valves, liquid pump, and other miscellaneous equipment. From time-to-time throughout the year numerous portable nurse tanks may also be present at the site. The anhydrous ammonia plant is only operated on a seasonal basis. Full-time equivalent employee numbers are computed on this basis. The FTEs for this company location is eight (8).

The aqua ammonia plant consists of two (2) storage tanks with associated piping, valves, pump, convertor, and other miscellaneous equipment. Aqua ammonia is manufactured on an ass needed basis throughout the entire year. There is one (1) full-time employee assigned routine responsibility for this plant.

THE WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS:

The worst case scenario for the anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia plants is the failure of the single largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed resulting in the release of the total volume. In the case of the anhydrous ammonia plant, the total volume is released in a gaseous (hazardous ammonia vapor cloud) form. According to EPA's RMP*Comp Program (Version 1.07), the distance to endpoint is 4.4 miles. In the ca

se of the aqua ammonia plant, the total volume is released in a liquid form. According to EPAA¿s RMP*Comp Program, the distance to endpoint is 1 mile.

The alternative release scenario for the anhydrous ammonia plant involves the transport delivery vehicle pulling away from the intake line manifold without disconnecting the transfer hoses. The resulting release according to EPA's RMP*Comp Program has a distance to endpoint of 0.1 miles. Similarly, a transfer line failure at the aqua ammonia plant has a distance to endpoint, according to EPA's RMP*Comp Program of 0.1 miles.

The systems are protected from major release (one or more of the following) by internal excess flow valves, check valves, relief valves, manual shutoff valves, and remote emergency shutoff valves. The load out risers used in filling nurse tanks at the anhydrous ammonia plant are protected by breakaway couplers designed to stop the flow of ammonia if the line or a hose breaks. All of the main storage tank valves are locked when not in use and the plant(s) are left unattended.

Since this facility is located in relatively close proximity of metropolitan areas, schools, a major transportation artery, etc. provisions have been designed to notify affected persons. Copies of the Risk Management Plan have been distributed to the Brighton Fire District and the Adams County LEPC.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and applicable State and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standard K61.1 and State law.

In addition the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release. Finally, Agfinity Incorporated has extended to the Brighton Fire District the opportunity to visit our facilities, to participate in mock eme

rgency simulation training, and to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia health hazard information and training provided by the company.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

Agfinity Incorporated has never had an accident involving anhydrous ammonia or qua ammonia that caused death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering-in-place.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia and/or aqua ammonia it is the policy of Agfinity Incorporated to immediately notify the Brighton Fire District and the Adams County LEPC to request that they respond to the emergency. In the unlikely event that the Fire District is unable to adequately respond to the emergency, the fire department(s) with which Brighton Fire District has mutual aid agreements will be summoned. We have discussed this policy with the Fire District and the Adams County LEPC.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia and/or aqua ammonia. Employees working at the plants make routine visual observations prior to and during transfer operations from storage vessels to transportation equipment whether portable nurse tanks or tank trucks. In so doing they are able to detect visible problems before they arise. This visual inspection identifies potions of the systems which may be under stress and about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize hazards associated with the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia and/or aqua ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires. The training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine the individual comprehension and underst

anding of the new hire. Finally, the company routinely invites Fire District personnel to visit the site(s). In the event that the Fire District requests assistance in training its employees on anhydrous ammonia and/or aqua ammonia the company cooperates fully in their endeavors.
